p.s: The Merchant of Venice, written by William Shakespeare is a play about a bond between a Christian and a Jew which leaves the Jew losing everything in the end.
This play could have some antisemeticanti-semetic aspects in it.
But does it raise awareness for the problem or does it fuel antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes?

One argument for the play raising awareness for the problem is that it was Shakespeare's intention to show the problems of the society he lived in, where Jews had to deal with discrimination and violence.
But this play could only be seen as a criticism of society if the audience have the right knowledge about the times Shakespeare lived in, the Elizabethan Age.
An argument that this play only fuels antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes is taht Shylock has, as said in 2) , mostly negative and stereotypical character traits.
He for example loves money more than his daughter, exploits his friends and is depicted as being inheritantlyinherently bad.
This could lead to the audience thining that all Jews are the way Shylock is.
This is onlyunderlined byt he fact that Shylock is often referred to as the Jew throughout the whole play, which strongly suggests that all Jews are like him and they all have his bad qualities.
By saying the Jew the audience thinks that he stands as a symbol for all Jews.

Another argument for The Merchant of Venice raisesraising awareness for the problem is that if you look at the play from Shylock's perspective it becomes a play about a Jew that has been mistreated his whole life and loses everything in the process but still stays true to his religion.
It would become a play that strongly suggests that there needs to be change in the society.
But if you hypothetically imagine how an antisemeticanti-semetic audience would react to this play it would again become a play that fuels antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes.
What also underlines this is that The Merchant of Venice was one of Adolf Hitler's favorite plays.

All in all one can say that if oyu interpret it the right way it could be raising awareness for the problem but I think it only fuels antisemeticanti-semeticstereotypes because of the reasons mentioned above.
I think The Merchant of Venice should not be read or played in theatre anymore because its view of the world is antisemeticanti-semetic and outdated.
